Introduction. Random samples. Summary Statistics, MLE

Probability: in probability we start with a probability model PPP, and we deduce properties of PPP.

E.g. Imagine flipping a coin 5 times. Assuming that flips are fair and independent, what is the probability of getting 2 heads?

Statistics: in statistics we have data, which we regard as having been generated from some unknown probability model PPP. We want to be able to say some useful things about PPP.

Definition. A random sample of size nnn is a set of random variables X1,...,XnX_1 , . . . , X_nX1​,...,Xn​ which are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.).

often you will compute the joint pmf of X1,...,XnX_1,...,X_nX1​,...,Xn​. This joint pmf gives you the probability you observe the sample data x1,...,xnx_1,...,x_nx1​,...,xn​,

In probability we assume that parameters λλλ and µµµ in our two examples are known. In statistics we wish to estimate λλλ and µµµ from data.

  • What is the best way to estimate them? And what does “best” mean?
  • For a given method, how precise is the estimation?

Sample mean and Sample variance, sample standard deviation

Denominator in sample variance is n−1n-1n−1, so that the sample variance will be what is called an unbiased estimator of the population variance. If we divide by nnn our sample variance would be underestimating the TRUE variance on average. We need to divide by the degrees of freedom, not the number of samples! stack _ Given observations x1,...,xnx_1,...,x_nx1​,...,xn​ we can compute the observed values xxx and s2s^2s2 .

We use sample mean, variance, standard deviation to estimate the TRUE unknown mean, variance, standard deviation.

MLE = Maximum Likelihood Estimation Maximum likelihood estimation is a general method for estimating unknown parameters from data.

Definition. Let X1,...,XnX_1,...,X_nX1​,...,Xn​ have joint p.d.f./p.m.f(x;θ)f(x; θ)f(x;θ). Given observed values x1,...,xnx_1,...,x_nx1​,...,xn​ of the likelihood of θθθ is the function: L(θ)=f(x;θ)L(θ) = f (x; θ)L(θ)=f(x;θ)

L(θ)L(\theta)L(θ) is the joint pmf, pdf of the observed data and is regarded as a function of θ\thetaθ for fixed xxx.

Definition. The maximum likelihood estimate (MLE) is the value θ^\hat{\theta}θ^ that maximizes the likelihood L(θ)L(\theta)L(θ) (or log-likelihood).

The idea of maximum likelihood is to estimate the parameter θ\thetaθ that gives the greates likelihood to the obsrvations x1,...,xnx_1,...,x_nx1​,...,xn​.

Estimator:

  • A rule for constructing an estimate.
  • A function of the random variables XXX involved in the random sample.
  • Itself a random variable. Estimate:
  • The numerical value of the estimator for the particular data set.
  • The value of the function evaluated at the data x1,...,xnx_1,...,x_nx1​,...,xn​.

Parameter estimation

Definition. A statistic is any function T(X)T(X)T(X) of X1,...,XnX_1,...,X_nX1​,...,Xn​ that does not depend on θ\thetaθ.

Definition. An estimator of θθθ is any statistic T(X)T(X)T(X) that we might use to estimate θθθ.

Definition. T(x)T(x)T(x) is the estimate of θθθ obtained via TTT from observed values xxx.

We can choose between estimators by studying their properties. A good estimator should take values close to the TRUE parameter θθθ.

Definition. An estimator T=T(X)T=T(X)T=T(X) is unbiased for θ\thetaθ if E(T)=θE(T) = \thetaE(T)=θ. This means that “on average” TTT is correct.

Definition. The mean squared error (MSE) of an estimator TTT is defined by MSE(T)=E[(T−θ)2].MSE(T) = E[(T − θ)^2].MSE(T)=E[(T−θ)2].

Definition. The bias b(T)b(T)b(T) of TTT is defined by b(T)=E(T)−θb(T) = E(T) − θb(T)=E(T)−θ.

MSE is a measure of the “distance” between TTT and the true parameter θθθ

However MSE(T)MSE(T)MSE(T) and b(T)b(T)b(T) may depend on θ\thetaθ.

Note MSE(T)=var(T)+b(T)2MSE(T) = var(T) + b(T)^2MSE(T)=var(T)+b(T)2 (bias variance trade-off)

So an estimator with small MSE needs to have small variance and small bias.

MLEs are usually asymptotically unbiased, and have MSE decreasing like 1/n1/n1/n for large nnn.

USE MSE(T) to compare different estimators for θ\thetaθ.

Accuracy of estimation: Confidence Intervals

A crucial aspect of statistics is not just to estimate a quantity of interest, but to assess how accurate or precise that estimate is. One approach is to find an interval, called a confidence interval (CI) within which we think the true parameter falls.

Definition. If a(X)a(X)a(X) and b(X)b(X)b(X) are two statistics, and 0<α<10 < α < 10<α<1, the interval (a(X),b(X))(a(X), b(X))(a(X),b(X)) is called a confidence interval for θθθ with confidence level 1−α1 − α1−α if, for all θθθ:

P(a(X)<θ<b(X))=1−αP(a(X) < θ < b(X)) = 1 − αP(a(X)<θ<b(X))=1−α

The interval (a(x),b(x))(a(x), b(x))(a(x),b(x)) is called an interval estimate and the random interval (a(X),b(X))(a(X), b(X))(a(X),b(X)) is called an interval estimator.

Note: a(X)a(X)a(X) and b(X)b(X)b(X) do not depend on θθθ.

We want small intervals and P(a(X)<θ<b(X))P(a(X) < \theta < b(X))P(a(X)<θ<b(X)) to be large.

By the same argument as before, if X1,...,Xn∼N(µ,σ02)X_1 , . . . , X_n ∼ N(µ, σ_{0}^{2})X1​,...,Xn​∼N(µ,σ02​) with σ02σ_{0}^{2}σ02​ known, then a level 1−α1 − α1−α confidence interval for µµµ is

(Xˉ−zα/2σ0n,Xˉ+zα/2σ0n)(\bar{X}-\dfrac{z_{\alpha/2} \sigma_{0}}{\sqrt{n}}, \bar{X}+\dfrac{z_{\alpha/2} \sigma_{0}}{\sqrt{n}})(Xˉ−n​zα/2​σ0​​,Xˉ+n​zα/2​σ0​​)

The more data I have the smaller interval I get!

if variance is unknown use SAMPLE VARIANCE (division by n−1n-1n−1).

Interpretation of a Confidence Interval

  • The parameter θ\thetaθ is fixed but unknown.
  • If we imagine repeating our experiment then we’d get new data, x′x'x′ say, and hence we’d get a new confidence interval a(x′),b(x′)a(x'), b(x')a(x′),b(x′). If we did this repeatedly we would “catch” the true parameter value about 95%95\%95% of the time, for a 95%95\%95% confidence interval: i.e. about 95% of our intervals would contain θθθ.
  • The confidence level is a coverage probability, the probability that the random confidence interval a(X),b(X)a(X), b(X)a(X),b(X) covers the true θ. (It’s a random interval because the endpoints a(X),b(X)a(X), b(X)a(X),b(X) are random variables.)

You always get confidence interval estimates. You cannot say (523,3313)(523,3313)(523,3313) is 95\% confidence interval. It either does or does not contain the TRUE parameter θ\thetaθ. You cant say which as θ\thetaθ is unknown.

Linear Regression

Suppose we measure two variables in the same population:

  • xxx: the explanatory variable, predictor, feature, input
  • yyy: the response variable, output

A linear regression model for the dependence of yyy on xxx is:

yi=α+βxi+ϵiy_{i} = \alpha + \beta x_{i} + \epsilon_{i}yi​=α+βxi​+ϵi​

where:

  • x1,...,xn,y1...,ynx_1,...,x_n, y_1...,y_nx1​,...,xn​,y1​...,yn​ are known constants (data points)
  • ϵ1,...,ϵn\epsilon_1,..., \epsilon_{n}ϵ1​,...,ϵn​ are i.i.d. N(0,σ2)N(0,\sigma^{2})N(0,σ2) "random errors"
  • α,βα, βα,β are unknown parameters. The “random errors” represent random scatter of the points (xi,yi)(x_i, y_i)(xi​,yi​) about the line y=α+βxy = α + βxy=α+βx, we do not expect these points to lie on a perfect straight line.

Note: a linear relationship like this does not necessarily imply that xxx causes yyy.

Goal: estimate α\alphaα and β\betaβ

Assessing model fit

Having fitted a model = estimated the parameters β\betaβ.

Having fitted a model, we should consider how well it fits the data. A model is normally an approximation to reality: is the approximation sufficiently good that the model is useful?

Definition. The i-th fitted value is yi^=xiβ^\hat{y_i} = x_{i}\hat{\beta}yi​^​=xi​β^​

The i-th residual is ei=yi−yi^e_{i} = y_{i}-\hat{y_{i}}ei​=yi​−yi​^​

The RSS (residual sum of squares) is RSS=∑eiRSS = \sum e_{i}RSS=∑ei​

The RSE (residual standard error) is RSE=RSSn−pRSE = \sqrt{\dfrac{RSS}{n-p}}RSE=n−pRSS​​ (this is an estimate of the standard deviation σ\sigmaσ).

Potential problem: non-linearity

A residual plot is a useful graphical tool for identifying non-linearity: for simple linear regression we can plot the residuals eie_iei​ against the fitted values yi^\hat{y_{i}}yi​^​ . Ideally the plot will show no pattern. The existence of a pattern may indicate a problem with some aspect of the linear model.

Potential problem: non-constant variance of errors

Non-constant variance is also called heteroscedasticity. Can see funnel-type shape in the residual plot.

How might we deal with non-constant variance of the errors?

  • One possibility is to transform the response Y using a transformation such as log(Y)log(Y)log(Y) or Y\sqrt{Y}Y​ (which shrinks larger responses more), leading to a reduction in heteroscedasticity.
  • If you know how variances behave for YiY_iYi​ and think var(Yi)=var(ϵi)=σ2/wivar(Y_i)=var(\epsilon_i) = \sigma^{2}/w_{i}var(Yi​)=var(ϵi​)=σ2/wi​ you can take the approach called weighted least squares minimizing ∑i=1nwi(yi−xiβ)\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_i(y_i-x_i\beta)∑i=1n​wi​(yi​−xi​β)

Potential problem: outliers

An outlier is a point for which yiy_{i}yi​ is far from the value yi^\hat{y_i}yi​^​ predicted by the model.

If we believe an outlier is due to an error in data collection, then one solution is to simply remove the observation from the data and re-fit the model. However, an outlier may instead indicate a problem with the model, e.g. a nonlinear relationship between YYY and xxx, so care must be taken.

studentized residuals = standardized residuals greater than 3 is signal for outlier

Potential problem: high leverage points

(Trailstone group interview...)

Outliers are observations for which the response yiy_iyi​ is unusual given the value of xix_ixi​.

On the other hand, observations with high leverage have an unusual value of xix_ixi​ .

Definition the leverage of the ith observation is hih_{i}hi​ where

$h_{i} = \dfrac{1}{n} + \dfrac{(x_i - \bar{x})^{2}}{\sum (x_j-\bar{x})^{2}}

Take-away: Points with high residuals pull the regression line towards them more than points with lower residuals (the more yi^\hat{y_i}yi​^​ are wrong the more the line goes towards them)

Points with unusual value of xix_ixi​ far from the mean pull ht regression line a lot too. These are called high leverage points.

Why does this matter? We should be concerned if the regression line is heavily affected by just a couple of points, because any problems with these points might invalidate the entire fit. Hence it is important to identify high leverage observations.

Data Analysis

Linear regression is an example of supervised learning Y XY ~ XY X.

In unsupervised learning you have only XXX. In this case you want to answer questions:

  1. Can we find a way to visualize the data that is informative?
  2. Can we compress the dataset without losing any relevant information?
  3. Can we find separate subgroups (or clusters) of observations that de- scribe the structure of the dataset?

Unsupervised learning can be more challenging than supervised learning, since the goal is more subjective than prediction of a response variable.

Exploratory data analysis is unsupervised learning.

PCA

Principal components analysis (PCA) finds a low-dimensional representation of the data that captures as much of the information in the dataset as possible.

PCA key points:

  • each component coming from PCA is a linear combination of the variables
  • each components looks for maximum varaibility in the data

components choose a good way to choose a projection that separates the two clusters

PCA is maximization problem. Tofind componene α1\alpha_{1}α1​:

Biplots shows pair of PC-s how they cluster the data. It uses the data projection on the principal components.

The total amount of variance in the original data matrix X is the sum of the diagonal entries in SSS.

It is common practice to plot the decreasing sequence of eigenvalues to visualize ths structure in the dataset. Such plots are sometimes refered to as eigenspectrum plots or variance scree plots, and usually they are scaled so each bar is percentage of the total variance.

Question

Apply PCA to raw data or to transformed data?

The first principal component maximises the variance of a linear combination of variables. If the variables have very different levels of variability then maximizing the projection with the largest variance may tend to dominate the first principal component.

For this reason, it can sometimes make sense to standardize the variables before PCA

This can be achieved by applying PCA to the sample correlation matrix R, rather than the sample covariance matrix S.

It can be shown (see Exercises) that the PCA components derived from using S are not the same as those derived from using R, and knowledge of one of these sets of components does not enable the other set to be derived.

Clustering

PCA provides low dimensional represeantaion of the data and show groupings of observations when visualized. It does not provide labelling.

Clustering refers to a very broad set of techniques for finding subgroups, or clusters, in a dataset.

K-means

To perform KKK-means clustering we must first decide upon the number of clusters KKK. The algorithm will assign each observation to excatly one of the KKK clusters.

Goals:

  • minimize within distance between points in same cluster
  • maximize distance between observations from different clusters

K-means algo explicitly tackles the first goal by finding a local minimum. Finiding global minimum would require goind through all partitions of nnn elements in kkk subsets which is factoriel like (Stirling numbers).

The two goals above are actually equivalent see

noteIndex.body: Welcome to my Knowledge Base! Here I write about my perception of life, document exciting things I've learned, debate (with myself) on controversial topics. If you know me you will not be surprised to find out that I write mostly about engineering and maths. Other topics I'm interested in are economics, politics, business, chess and poker.
